text: after four decades in solitary
confinement Albert Woodfox one of the
so-called Angola three is to be released
but what happens when someone who spent
so long behind bars without any human
interaction is released
I was already angry and it made me a lot
more angry and eventually the anger to
me as I look back reflectively the anger
within me to a point where you know I
believed that I could have possibly
taken somebodies like just like that
just based on that the intensity of
anger inside of me at that time and so I
avoided having conversations with people
particularly around subjects such as my
incarceration being released back into
everyday life after years in solitary
confinement poses huge challenges and
for some it's simply too much earlier
this week 22 year-old kalief Browder
who'd been held without trial at the
notorious Rikers Island prison in New
York committed suicide I probably would
have fed a lot better had I actually had
a plan and had a well structured and
committed support network somebody we've
been through you know kind of been
through so at least some of what I've
been through in this prison it's
estimated there were around eighty
thousand prisoners who are in solitary
confinement across the United States for
some that means spending 23 hours a day
in cramped conditions with maybe an hour
for exercise so of course the challenges
of entering everyday life are huge many
people often assume that solitary
confinement is a quiet place and in fact
the reality is solitary confinement is
assaulting Lea loud you're hearing on
either side of you the sounds of
deterioration of the people around you
to then be released onto the streets
there's this there's this profound
disorientation with the world around you
